content_html:
“Please don’t share that you got a bonus,” my manager whispered to me in the same sort of lowered voice usually reserved for the juiciest office gossip. I was just leaving the one-on-one meeting where I’d gotten the good news — one of several such bonus-related meetings happening that day — and I knew that within the next 24 hours, our open-plan office would be abuzz with information about who had and hadn’t received one. Still, I agreed, mumbling, “Okay,” on my way out.

A few hours later, one of the women in my four-person desk cluster approached me to share, in hushed tones, that one of our colleagues hadn’t gotten a bonus. “How much did you get?” she added.

Unsure if my manager’s directive was a request or a command, I hesitated, trying to quickly run through the potential ramifications of sharing this information. What would it mean if it got back to this other colleague of ours that I had received a bonus when she, a superior, hadn’t?

Thus began the mental gymnastics done in offices everywhere: When faced with the conundrum about whether or not to talk about salaries with your co-workers, what do you do?

Outside of a select few especially close relationships, we’re conditioned not to ask each other about money. But hiding behind social niceties is doing us all a disservice.

“It’s in our best interest to know” what our co-workers and industry peers are making, says Ashley Feinstein Gerstley, author of The 30-Day Money Cleanse and founder of the blog The Fiscal Femme. “When we don’t know, [companies] win the game because they have more negotiating power. When we have more transparency, we can know more readily what the value is for a certain role.”

Plus, open conversations about salary may help drive necessary systemic change to lessen the gender wage gap and push us toward more equitable pay. “We want to move towards a more fair and equitable system where your pay is based on your skill set in the marketplace and what you’re producing in combination with your experience,” says Alex Dickinson, who founded Ask For It, a company dedicated to helping people learn how to become better negotiators. “It shouldn’t be about how good of a negotiator you are. It should be more of a marketplace system.”

“But,” she adds, “it’s easier said than done.”

Can your employer prevent you from having this discussion?

Under the National Labor Relations Act, it’s illegal for most — but not all — employers to bar workers from discussing salary or fire them for doing so. According to the website of the National Labor Relations Board, the act doesn’t apply to anyone considered a supervisor or independent contractor, and some employers are exempt entirely, including “federal, state, or local governments; employers who employ only agricultural workers; and employers subject to the Railway Labor Act.”

Legal protection in theory doesn’t always translate to legal protection in practice; even if it’s illegal to fire you over salary discussions, some companies, particularly in the private sector, may be willing to take the risk and do so anyway. Perhaps they assume you won’t actually pursue legal action, or they’re willing to pay any fines levied against them by the National Labor Relations Board in order to maintain pay secrecy. Or they may look for other fireable offenses as a pretense for letting you go in order to uphold their case in court. To go into salary conversations as prepared as possible, it helps to have a sense of the risk; take into account the policies and culture of your office before approaching your co-workers.

Who should you ask?

To get an accurate read on where you fall in terms of salary, your sample size needs to be more than one or two people. In fact, Dickinson, who now works as a membership strategy lead at the personal finance company SoFi, recommends reaching out to at least six people, ideally three men and three women.

If you’re in sales and your best friend is in marketing at the same company, their information isn’t going to be helpful.

Dickinson recommends using your judgment about whether you should approach someone, taking into account both office politics and the trustworthiness of the person you plan to ask. You also need to seek out people whose information is relevant to you — asking someone in a different department or role about their salary, when it’s clear their answer won’t be applicable to your own situation, can come off as nosy or intrusive. If you’re in sales and your best friend is in marketing at the same company, for instance, their information isn’t going to be helpful.

You can also look for people outside your office. “I love to do cold reach-outs to people I think would be useful,” says Dickinson, noting that LinkedIn can be a useful source here. Feinstein Gerstley also suggests reaching out to people who did your job but recently left your company and says you can ask friends to tap their extended networks. Just make sure that anyone you approach is at a company of a similar type and size and, ideally, in the same geographic location.

This also holds true for the self-employed. It’s incredibly important to reach out to people who do similar work and ask them about their rates to gauge if you’re charging enough in your market.

Once you have your people picked out, how do you start this conversation?

It can be a nerve-wracking topic to broach, so don’t go in without a plan for what to say. “I give people a script with three lines and an optional fourth one,” says Dickinson:

  1. “I am doing some research because I’m about to [insert reason, such as ask for a raise or interview for a new job].”
  2. “I think you have some information that could help me.” Reasons for this include: You have a similar job to me at another company, or you recently did my job and got promoted, or you hire for my job.
  3. “Would you be willing to share your ballpark salary with me?” Or, in the case of asking a person who hires for your job, you can say, “I’m thinking of asking for X. Does that sound reasonable to you?”

The optional fourth line: “And I’d be happy to follow up with you afterward to let you know how it turns out.” Dickinson suggests using this line when approaching people cold, as curiosity might be the factor that pushes a complete stranger to help you out.

Feinstein Gerstley suggests easing yourself in by starting with the person who feels the least daunting to approach. If you’re feeling uncomfortable, you can acknowledge the potential awkwardness of your ask while also framing the conversation around why it’s important to know market rates.

What happens if you discover a pay gap?

“What do you do with that information is more important than how you talk about it,” says James Orsini, president of the Sasha Group, a consulting firm that caters to startups and small businesses.

If you unearth evidence of unfair payment practices, Orsini recommends going directly to human resources for clarification about the factors that go into your salary and the company’s decision on salary ranges. To accurately compare, you need the full picture: Orsini highlights background, education, prior experience, different degrees, willingness to relocate, and cost of living as factors that could all affect why two employees with the same title are making different salaries. It’s also why companies may set up salary bands.

If you’re planning to ask for a raise, these are all useful data points that can help you frame your own argument more effectively. But if you plan to use your co-workers’ information in your own job negotiation, it’s incredibly important not to name names and throw them under the bus — when you’re talking to your bosses, frame your research in broad terms rather than comparing yourself directly to one other person in the office. (If, based on your findings and your interactions with your bosses and HR, you still believe there’s systemic discrimination happening, you can file a claim with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.)

Where else can you turn?

If cold messaging people on LinkedIn, reaching out to your extended network, or talking bluntly with your co-workers all seem too uncomfortable, you can still turn to the internet for assistance. Sites like Glassdoor.com, Salary.com, Payscale.com, Comparably.com, Career Contessa’s The Salary Project, and SoFi’s Get That Raise should give you at least a rough idea of what other people in your role are making. You can also research if there are any databases that aggregate information specific to your industry, such as this Google spreadsheet from 2018, in which people working in television shared their salaries. The numbers gleaned from these websites won’t be as specific or applicable as information you could get from talking to other people, so it could be helpful to consider them a first step rather than an endgame — but still, any data at all is better than staying uninformed.

A Step-by-Step Guide to Talking About Salary With Your Co-Workers

How to initiate an awkward but necessary conversation

Erin Lowry
Feb 1

Credit: ilyaliren/iStock/Getty Images Plus

Credit: ilyaliren/iStock/Getty Images Plus

Loading…
0:00
9:02

“Please don’t share that you got a bonus,” my manager whispered to me in the same sort of lowered voice usually reserved for the juiciest office gossip. written by

Erin Lowry

Writer, speaker, and author of Broke Millennial: Stop Scraping By and Get Your Financial Life Together and Broke Millennial Takes On Investing.
